Award.AwardTitle: Adaptive System Based on Macro-Fiber Composite Transducers for Vibration Control and Noise Reduction in Wind Turbine Blades

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to improve the performance of wind turbine blades for renewable energy generation by mitigating the blade vibrations, hence reducing the airborne noise and increasing the blade?s fatigue life.
The approach is to integrate with the blade a distributed network of piezo-composite patches to mitigate low-frequency vibrations (< 100Hz) through active piezoelectric actuation and high-frequency vibrations (>100 Hz) through passive shunt damping.

Intellectual Merit
Vibrations in wind turbines result in both airborne noise affecting surrounding areas, and increased lifecycle cost of the turbine from structural fatigue. The project will complement existing "global" control of wind turbine blades by reducing vibrations at a more "local" scale using a distributed network of piezo-composite patches. Piezo-composite patches, compared to monolithic piezoelectric disks, offer increased durability, conformability to curved surfaces, and better compatibility with the composite blade material. The network will also provide a multi-scale vibration suppression capability that is unprecedented in wind turbines.

Broader Impacts
Wind currently accounts for 42% of the installed renewable power in the U.S. One of the Grand Challenges of the Department of Energy is to have 20% of the U.S. energy generated by wind by 2030. The proposed piezo-composite network will reduce airborne noise levels to surrounding areas and will increase the operating regime and the structural life of the blades. The project will also include the modification of an existing course at UCSD, international research cooperation, and outreach efforts to low-income 6-12 grade students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A recent report from the American Wind Energy Association ranks Wind as the primary source of Renewable Energy in the U.S. The Department of Energy has set the target of wind producing 20% of the U.S. electric supply by 2030.

The performance of a wind turbine is driven by several factors. One critical factor is, of course, structural integrity. Wind turbine blades are made primarily of light-weight composite materials. Structural defects in the composite blades can be introduced during the blade’s manufacturing process, or generated in service by, for example, vibration-induced fatigue. As a primary component of the turbine, the rotor blades are built to withstand many fatigue cycles during their lifetime, which can exceed that of a typical bridge or commercial aircraft. Complicating the design requirements even further are the highly stochastic wind conditions that drive the rotor blades.

The research at UCSD was focused on achieving the following technical capabilities: (1) detect and image structural defects in the blades, and (2) mitigate unwanted vibrations in the blades to minimize fatigue exposure. The defect detection and imaging approach was focused on a passive ultrasonic method exploiting the natural wind excitations on the blade to detect and image structural damage. As a complement to the ultrasonic approach, statistically-enhanced Infrared Thermography was applied to the defect detection in the blades. For vibration mitigation, shunt damping from Macro-Fiber Composite (MFC) patches was studied.

These techniques were experimentally tested on a 9-m long CX-100 wind turbine blade that was specifically designed and built for this project, and that is currently housed at UCSD’s Powell Research Laboratories. The CX-100 research blade was fabricated by TPI composites in collaboration with the Wind Power Group of Sandia National Laboratory. The blade contains over 45 documented defects of different sizes and types that are commonly encountered in real-world turbines.

The research showed that the proposed passive ultrasonic method was indeed able to detect several defects in the CX-100 test blade, including delaminations and holes. Defect imaging was also possible as it related to a defect simulated with clay. The enhanced infrared thermographic technique was proven to be a useful complement to the ultrasound test for rapid defect imaging.  It was also shown that the MFC sensors, once appropriately located, can indeed dampen high-frequency vibrations which could otherwise contribute to defect growth and reduced life of the turbine. Ultimately, this research will contribute to the development of inspection standards for composite wind turbine blades, that are currently under development by several research groups worldwide.

The work carried out for this project has potential applications to other damage-prone structures that can benefit from structural health monitoring solutions. The passive damage detection technique is particularly applicable to structures that are subjected to random natural excitations, and that are typically challenging to inspect with classical methods. These structures include aircraft, marine vessels, and even oil pipelines. The statistical processing developed for the infrared thermography defect detection can be used for anomaly detection in other fields, such as imagery surveillance and pollution monitoring.

The project trained two PhD graduate students and two undergraduate students. Elements of the research were incorporated in a graduate-level class, SE252, and an undergraduate-level class, SE163, both taught by the PI at UCSD yearly. Some of the research results have also led to a new project that has been funded by NSF in 2014 and that aims at further improving the defect quantification abilities of infrared thermography on composite structures.
